Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Environmentally-driven coupling of selection and heritability in a wild insect population
Award.AbstractNarration:
Environmental variation can dramatically alter trait evolution in wild populations because it affects two drivers of adaptive evolution: natural selection and heritability (the resemblance between parents and offspring). Variation in selection among environments is common; intriguingly, recent studies demonstrate that the environment also affects heritability. Consequently, environmental variation may generate a systematic association between these two forces, which could accelerate evolution if selection is strongest in the same environment that produces high heritability. The proposed work will examine environmental coupling of selection and heritability in a male trait (horns) in wild populations of forked fungus beetles (Bolitotherus cornutus). The proposed work will measure selection on horn length in ten beetle populations from three different fungal environments and estimate the heritability of horn length in the same populations. These data will be used to measure the correlation between selection and heritability and quantify its effect on the predicted response to selection.

Understanding factors that constrain adaptive evolution under varying environmental conditions is particularly important in the context of climate change. In addition, the project involves training of a graduate student and mentorship of undergraduate students. Components of the project will be used in workshops for the Mountain Lake Biological Station partnership with local educators in rural southwestern Virginia. The research results will be disseminated in scientific journals, academic conferences, and interdisciplinary symposia, such as the Jefferson Scholars Foundation?s Forum for Interdisciplinary Dialogue.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The rate of adaptive evolution depends on the strength of selection acting on a trait and the amount of heritable genetic variation underlying the trait. Because the environment affects both selection and genetic variation, local environmental conditions can substantially accelerate or impede evolutionary change. The goal of this project was to examine how differences in the environment affect selection and genetic variation in a natural beetle metapopulation (Bolitotherus cornutus) that relies on three host fungi. 

We found that the strength of selection on body size in B. cornutus varied significantly among the three fungal hosts. On two of the three fungi (Fomes fomentarius and Ganoderma applanatum) larger beetles of both sexes produced more offspring, while there was no selection acting on body size on the third fungus (Ganoderma tsugae). To estimate heritability—which requires a pedigree—we enclosed all fungus fruiting bodies in mesh cages to capture emerging offspring and used genetic markers to determine their parentage.  We discovered that both development time and mortality rates differ strikingly among fungi. Beetles developing in Ganoderma tsugae—an annually fruiting species—emerge within a year, while those developing in Fomes fomentarius and Ganoderma applanatum—perennially fruiting species—take two or more years to emerge as adults. Moreover, mortality is so high on Fomes fomentarius that few individuals survive to adulthood. 

The results of this project demonstrate that the environment is a significant source of variation in fitness and selection in a natural population, and that the environment generates this variation through a complex combination of indirect and direct effects in the juvenile and adult life stages. In spite of the severe mortality costs and long development time associated with F. fomentarius, however, we found that our focal metapopulation continues to exploits all three fungi in the wild. Ovipositing females preferred the highest-quality host in laboratory trials, but this preference was not apparent in the field, where the poorest-quality host comprises 70% of the resource community. These results suggest that unmeasured costs or constraints in the wild underlie the persistent use of all three fungal hosts, underscoring the influence of landscape ecology on evolution in heterogeneous environments.

This project supported the primary dissertation work of the co-PI, who successfully defended her dissertation in April 2015 and started a post-doctoral research position at the University of Toronto in August 2015. This project also supported the mentorship of four undergraduate students (two from under-represented groups in science) through the National Science Foundation Research Experiences for Undergraduates program at Mountain Lake Biological Station (MLBS), and two independent research students at the University of Virginia. All six students designed and executed their own research projects under the supervision of the PI and co-PI, one of which was published in Behavioral Ecology, a peer-reviewed scientific journal (Wood et al. 2014). Of these six students, three are currently in PhD programs and two are working in research labs. In 2014 and 2015, this project formed the basis for the introductory workshop at the beginning of the MLBS REU program. In addition, the co-PI incorporated this project in outreach events with visiting high school groups and at the MLBS open house for the general public.
